Well, vaccine development, it's always been a very trial and error process.
It really hasn't been much driven by our knowledge of the immune system.
And so, my lab and certainly many others have been trying to fill those gaps.
And so, what we've said is, okay, well, you know, what do you want?
You want protective antibody.
So, well how do you get those?
Well, you need helper T-cells, which are also CD4 T-cells or I might just call them helper cells.
Mm-hmm.
And so then, you say, okay.
So then, what do you need those helper T-cells to do?
Or, which helper T-cells do you need?
And so, what's been known is that there are like four different kinds of helper T-cells, okay, or four flavors of helper T-cells.
And each of these are - they're specialized for different functions.
So, these helper T-cells, they're very powerful regulators of the immune system.
Your immune system can do many different things and each of these four types of helper T-cells are, sort of, specialized for controlling different parts.
And the problem was none of these four known types of helper T-cells, these four flavors, none of those who are specialized for helping get antibody responses.
And if you're somebody like me who's interested in vaccines, where you're like, well, I want to know how to get antibody responses, so, what's going on here?
And so either all four kinds of these cells, they can all do it, right?
Mm-hmm.
Or there was a fifth type and we were missing something.
And so that's sort of where we've been stuck for - I don't know, probably about 10 years.

With a much fighting back and forth about, you know, what might be right and, you know, I - so, a Nobel prize winner once said, you know, that there are two kinds of scientists, there are lumpers and there are dividers.
So the lumpers try and come up with a theory of everything, like connect everything together, and dividers try and break everything down and figure out, well, what's specialized to exactly do what.
And so, there was a lot of that argument going on and so we said, well, look if there really is this fifth kind, then there should be a gene, a single gene that turns on that type of CD4.
And we've said that because, well, that's the way it was to the other four types.

So we know there are these other four types, and one of these really fascinating things about the immune system is that for each of those other four types, there's a master gene, a master regulator gene, is what we call them.
